title.q: Mountain Phases: A Sketch in the Wairarapa

editionStmt.edition: Transcribed and edited by Philip Steer

lg.l: Looming in the twilight morn,
As giants Giants. The poem describes the mountains of the Tararua Range, which border the western edge of the Wairarapa plains. of dark midnight born;
Waiting for the op’ning day,
Catching high its earliest ray,
Like beacons to the valley deep,
Waking up its life from sleep.
Mists up-gath’ring from beneath,
Out river beds and sedgy heath;
While, in easy grace arising,
Ever varying forms devising.
And clothing all from head to feet
In dripping rain and colder sleet;
And the wind, in fitful chases,
Up the steeps and down the faces;
Clearing off, and bringing on
Gleams of sunshine all day long,
Till, the sun, in evening’s round,
Clears all off in calm profound.
Then, in purple tinted dress,
Beams the richest loveliness:
Azure depths, and golden streaks,
Mark the slopes and pointed peaks.
And, nobler too, in outline free,
Far as far as eye can see,
Fading in the distant blue,
Richer than the morning’s hue.
But the shadows dimmer grow
In the evening’s darker glow;
When the blacker shades of night
Shut all in from human sight.
